div1.p: IN THE UNITED STATES CIRCUIT COURT OF APPEALS, FOR THE NINTH CIRCUIT.

JAMES P. LAVIN, Immigrants Inspector, and SISTER M. ANGELIQUE, Sister Superior of the House of the Good Shepherd, Appelants vs. YVONNE LE FEVRE, GORGEETTE NORMAND, and MARIE LE FEVRE, Appellees.} no.948.
Appeal from the United States Circuit Court for the District of Washington, Northern Division.

Habeas corpus proceedings were instituted by counsel on behalf of the appellees in the Superior Court of the State of Washington for King County, alleging their illegal detention at Seattle by the appellant Sister Superior M. Angelique of the House of the Good shepherd, said detention being by authority and request of the appellant James P. Lavin, United States Immigrant Inspector, After the service of the writ of habeas corpus upon the Sister Superior, the appellants petitioned the UnitedStates Circuit Court for the District of Washington, Northern Division, for the removal oof the proceedings to the Circuit Court. Thereupon a writ of certiorari was issued to the State Court, and the proceedings removed to the Feferal court.

Thereafter, the appeallants made a return and answer to the petition for habeas corpus, showing that the appellant James P.
Lavin was a revenue officer and immigrant inspector for the Collection District of Pugget Sound; that the appellecs were natives of the Republic of France; that the appellant Lavin had theretofore, in the discharge of his duties as such officer, removed the appelles from the steamship "Rosalie" upon its arrival at Seattle from Victoria, British Columbia, from which port they had been brough to Seattle; that said removal was for the purpose of investigating whether they were immigrants properly entitled to enter the United States; that a board of special inquiry was convened, consisting of the tresury and revenue officers, in accordance with the law and the regulations of the Tresury Department, to determine the eligibility of the appelless to land in the United States; that upon such investigation it had been found and dettermined that appelless had, within one year prior thereto, been imported into the United States at the port of New York form France, for the purpose of prostitution; that it had been further found and determined that each of them was a pauper and likely to become a public charge; that it had been further founf that immediately prior to their having been taken and removed from said vessel; that upon such findings it had been determined that concluded by said voard that the appellees were not lawfuly entitled to be in or enter the United States, and that they should be deported and returned to the country to which they belonged and from whence they came. Thereafter the facts and dindings of said board of special inquiry were forwarded to the Secretary of the Tresury for the purpose of having the question of the country and port to which the appelles should be deported and returned, detemined by
said Secretery; that while said question was pending before the Secretary of the Tresury, the court made an order and judgment, finding the facts and causes of detention of the appelles by the appellants as set forth in the return, and finding further that the only action warranted by the goverment and its officers upon the facts found was the deportation and return of the appellees to Victoria, British Columbia, at the expense of the steamer bringing them to this county; and therupon the court entered an order and judgment according.Thereafter, the Secretary of the Tresury issued his warrant, directing the appellees James P. Lavin, Immigrant Inspector, to arrest the appellees and remove them to the port of New York for deportation to France. Upon the receipt of said warrant the appellant made a supplemental retun, showing the fact od the issuance of such warrant, and petitioned the court to modify its order and judgment by striking out so much thereof as required the appellant to retun the appelles to the steamship that nrougt them to Seattle, "to be by said vessel at its own expense returned to Victoria, British Colmbie", leaving the appellant Lavin free to carry into eddect the warrant of the Secretary ofthe Tresury, Upon a hearing upon this supplemental return and petition, the court found that the appellees had only been temporaly removed form the steamer bringing them to Victoria, from the purpose of examination as to their fitness as immigrants by the Tresury officials, and that the only action warranted under the law was the refusal to the appellees of the right to land in this county, and the only country to which they could be lawfully returned upon the refusal of the right to land was the country from which they has come immediately prior to such rejection, to wit, to British Columbia. The court founf that the appellees, not having landed in this country, and not having been found here, were not subject to deportation by warrant of the Secretary of the
Tresury to the county to which they belong and from which they originally came, to writ, France. The court thereupon denied the petition for a rehering and modification of the judgment, and ordered and directed the appellant James P. Lavin, Immigrant Inspector, to carry into effect the original order and judgment of this court. From these orderes and judgments the present appeal is prosecuted by the united States Anttorney, for and in behalf of the Immigrant Inspector and the Sister Superior of the House d the Good Shepherd.
Jesse A. Frye, U.S. Attorney, and Edward E. Cushman, Assistant U.S. Attorney, for the Appellants.
H.C. Gill, H.B. Hoyt, and H.S> Frys, Attorneys for the Appelles.
Before GILBERT, ROSS, and MORROW, Circuit Judges.
MORROW, Circuit Judge, delivered the opinion of the court;

The errors relied upon by the appellants are; First, that the question of the ddeportation of the appekkees was within the judgment and the jurisdiction of the Secretary of the Tresury, and not within the jurisdiction of the Circuit Court. Second that after assuming jurisdiction, the court erred in determinating, contrary to the determination of the Secretary of the Tresury, that the appellees should be return to British Columbia, and not to France.

The court below found the cause of the detention of the appellees
to be as set forth in the retur of the appellants to the writ of habeas corpus. This retun ahowed that the executive officers of the Goverment had upon investigation determined that the appellees were alien immigrants, and belonged to a class of persons excluded by law from coming to the United States; that upon such investigation it was found and determined that said immigrants had within one year prior therto been imported into the United States at the port of New York from France, from the purposes pf prostitution; that each of them was liable to become a public charge; that immediatl prior to being taken from the cessel that brought them to Seattle they had left the United States and gone to Victoria, from which place they were returning to the United States.
